metadata.title: <ce:italic>In-situ</ce:italic> formation of cobalt phosphide nanoparticles confined in three-dimensional porous carbon for high-performing zinc-air battery and water splitting

Article In-situ formation of cobalt phosphide nanoparticles confined in three-dimensional porous carbon for high-performing zinc-air battery and water splitting Xinxin Shu a † Maomao Yang a † Miaomiao Liu a Huaisheng Wang b Jintao Zhang a * a Key Laboratory for Colloid and Interface Chemistry of State Education Ministry, School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Shandong University, Jinan 250100, Shandong, China Key Laboratory for Colloid and Interface Chemistry of State Education Ministry School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Shandong University Jinan Shandong 250100 China Key Laboratory for Colloid and Interface Chemistry of State Education Ministry, School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Shandong University, Jinan 250100, Shandong, China b School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Liaocheng University, Liaocheng 252059, Shandong, China School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Liaocheng University Liaocheng Shandong 252059 China School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Liaocheng University, Liaocheng 252059, Shandong, China * Corresponding author. Tel: +86-531-88361011 Tel: +86-531-88361011 † Contributed equally to this work. Abstract The rational design of efficient and stable carbon-based electrocatalysts for oxygen reduction and oxygen evolution reactions is crucial for improving energy density and long-term stability of rechargeable zinc-air batteries (ZABs). Herein, a general and controllable synthesis method was developed to prepare three-dimensional (3D) porous carbon composites embedded with diverse metal phosphide nanocrystallites by interfacial coordination of transition metal ions with phytic acid-doped polyaniline networks and subsequent pyrolysis. Phytic acid as the dopant of polyaniline provides favorable anchoring sites for metal ions owing to the coordination interaction. Specifically, adjusting the concentration of adsorbed cobalt ions can achieve the phase regulation of transition metal phosphides. Thus, with abundant cobalt phosphide nanoparticles and nitrogen- and phosphorus-doping sites, the obtained carbon-based electrocatalysts exhibited efficient electrocatalytic activities toward oxygen reduction and evolution reactions. Consequently, the fabricated ZABs exhibited a high energy density, high power density of 368 mW cm−2, and good cycling/mechanical stability, which could power water splitting for integrated device fabrication with high gas yields. Graphical Abstract Three-dimensional porous carbon composites embedded with cobalt phosphide nanocrystallites are proposed to enhance the performance of Zn-air batteries and water splitting. Keywords Cobalt phosphide Three-dimensional porous carbon Electrocatalysis Zinc-air battery Water splitting 1 Introduction Rechargeable zinc-air batteries (ZABs) with low cost, good safety, and high energy density are promising supplementary and alternative batteries for Li-ion battery-dominant markets, including mobile communications and electric vehicles [1,2]. However, their practical implementation is limited by their low power density, short cycling life, and low energy efficiency, mainly because of the sluggish reaction kinetics and poor electrochemical reversibility for the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) and evolution reaction (OER) in air electrodes [3]. Therefore, extensive research has been devoted to exploring efficient and stable bifunctional electrocatalysts. Beyond noble metal-based electrocatalysts, low-cost and earth-abundant electrocatalysts have been developed using nanocarbons, non-noble metals, and carbon-based composites [4–6]. In particular, carbon-based composites with sophisticated structures have good stability and low-cost, offering opportunities to improve the electrocatalytic performance and stability [7,8]. Recent advances have shown that transition metal phosphides (TM x P y ) are a promising class of earth-abundant electrocatalysts for diverse catalytic reactions, such as hydrodesulfurization (HDS) and hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) [9]. Owing to its strong metal-phosphrous (M–P) bands, TM x P y exhibits good thermal stability and high oxidation resistance. In particular, phosphorus-rich TM x P y (y > x) has been confirmed as a highly active catalyst for HER [10]. The presence of P atoms in TM x P y increases the density of states near the Fermi level, resulting in low overpotential and fast reaction kinetics for hydrogen evolution [11,12]. However, the preparation of TM x P y usually requires introducing additional phosphorus sources such as PH3, (NH4)2HPO4, or NaH2PO2 [13–15]. Moreover, the direct organometallic decomposition strategy using triphenylphosphine (TPP) and trioctylphosphine (TOP) as phosphorus sources is relatively tedious. Hence, a facile synthetic strategy is highly desirable for designing advanced electrocatalysts for practical applications. Based on the superior electrocatalytic performance of TM x P y , carbon support incorporation is efficient for exploring their synergetic effects, thus enhancing electrocatalytic activity [16,17]. Thermal pyrolysis is generally used to transform precursors into carbon-based composites. However, high-temperature pyrolysis and carbothermic reactions inevitably accelerate the thermal decomposition of carbon and lead to severe aggregation of TM x P y nanoparticles, resulting in inferior catalytic performance [18]. The additive etching process is generally employed to remove aggregated particles [19,20]. To address these issues, porous carbon networks with large surface areas and highly conductive skeletons are required to anchor the TM x P y for electrocatalysis. Herein, we demonstrate a general method to synthesize 3D porous carbon electrocatalysts embedded with metal phosphide nanoparticles via the incorporation of interfacial coordination of phytic acid with metal ions and the in situ thermal carbonization of a doped polyaniline (PANI) network. With the desirable coordination ability of phytic acid, additional metal ions can be introduced into the porous PANI network. Without additional phosphorus sources, the present method efficiently integrates the formation of TM x P y and phosphorus doping via thermal carbonization. Notably, the as-prepared electrocatalysts with 3D porous carbon and cobalt phosphide nanocrystals synergistically improved the electrocatalytic ability and good durability for the ORR, OER, and HER. With efficient electrocatalytic activity, ZABs exhibit a high power density and good cycling stability in both aqueous and solid-state electrolytes. In particular, water splitting devices can be driven by fabricated ZABs, further demonstrating their multifunctional catalytic applications. 2 Experimental 2.1 Material preparation Five mL of phytic acid (50%, w/w in water) was added to 20 mL ultrapure water (18.25 MΩ cm) to form a dilute phytic acid solution. Two milliliters of aniline monomer were added to obtain the solution A. Ammonium persulphate (0.6 g) was dissolved in 5 mL water to obtain solution B. Two solutions were mixed together and kept at 4 °C overnight. After polymerization, the obtained hydrogel was immersed in deionized water and washed several times to obtain B-PANI-PA. F-PANI-PA was synthesized by adjusting the phytic acid to aniline ratio. Specifically, 5 mL of PA was added to 13 mL of deionized water, and then 3.2 mL aniline monomer was added, followed by the addition of 0.96 g in 5 mL deionized water. To obtain B-PANI-PA-Co and F-PANI-PA-Co, 50 mL 6.8 mmol L−1 cobalt nitrate solution was added to 50 mL B-PANI-PA or F-PANI-PA dispersion (6 mg mL−1) and stirred for 2 h, then washed and freeze-dried for 48 h. By adjusting the pH to 7.3, B-PANI-PA-Co-7.3 was obtained. PANI aerogels were pyrolyzed at 900 °C for 1 h under nitrogen at an increasing temperature rate of 5 °C min−1. When dwelling at 900 °C, NH3 (30 mL min−1) was injected into the tube and maintained for 30 min to obtain CoP X @B-NPC, CoP X @F-NPC, and CoP X @B-NPC-7.3. The same procedure was used to synthesize FeP X @B-NPC in the presence of iron (III) nitrate. B-PANI-PA-Co pyrolyzed under N2 atmosphere is denoted as B-NPC. 2.2 Characterization The morphology and microstructure were determined by field-emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM, ZEISS GeminiSEM 300), transmission electron microscopy (TEM, JEOL 2100 PLUS), and high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM, JEM-2100F). Ultraviolet-visible (UV-vis) spectra were obtained using a UV-Vis-NIR spectrometer (Cary 5000). Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectra were recorded using a FTIR spectrometer (Bruker Invenio S). The crystalline structure was recorded on an X-ray diffractometer (SmartLab 9KW) using Cu-Kα radiation (λ = 0.15418 nm). X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) were recorded using a photoelectron spectrometer (ESCALAB 250). High-resolution spectra were deconvoluted using XPSPEAK41 software and fitting with 20% Lorentzian-Gaussian function after Shirley type background subtraction. Raman spectra were recorded using a Raman spectrometer (LabRAM HR Evolution) under laser excitation at 532 nm. N2 sorption isotherms were recorded using a BJ Builder KuboX1000 instrument at –196 °C. 2.3 Electrochemical measurements Electrochemical evaluation was conducted on a CHI 760E workstation (CH Instrument, Shanghai) in a three-electrode setup with 0.1 mol L−1 KOH (1 mol L−1 KOH for OER/HER) as the electrolyte, an Ag/AgCl electrode, and a graphite rod as the reference and counter electrodes, respectively. The potential was converted to a reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE) according to the following equation: E RHE = E Ag/AgCl + 0.197 + 0.059pH. To prepare the catalyst ink, 5 mg of as-prepared catalysts were dispersed in a solution containing 0.05 mL Nafion (5 wt%, DuPont) and 0.95 mL ultrapure water under sonication, followed by dripping 8 μL of catalyst ink on the disk electrode of the rotating ring-disk electrode (RRDE) for the ORR test or 200 μL per side of catalyst ink on carbon paper (Shanghai Hesen Electric Co., Ltd, HCP330N) for the OER/HER test. Pt/C (20 wt%, Sigma-Aldrich) and RuO2 (Aladdin) references were prepared using the same procedure. LSV curves were obtained using RRDE at a rotation speed of 1600 rpm for ORR and using carbon paper with 90% iR-compensation for OER and HER evaluation. The kinetic current (i K) and electron transfer number (n) for ORR can be derived from the Koutecký-Levich equation [21]: (1) 1/j = 1/j l + 1/j k = 1/(0.2nFD O2 2/3 ω 1/2 ν −1/6 C O2) + 1/j k where j is the measured current density, j l is the diffusion-limiting current density, and j k is the kinetic current density. F is the Faraday constant (F = 96485 C mol−1), D O2 is the diffusion coefficient of O2 in 0.1 mol L−1 KOH (D O2 = 1.9 × 10−5 cm2 s−1), ω is the rotating rate, υ is the kinetic viscosity (υ = 0.01 cm2 s−1) and C O2 is the bulk concentration of O2 (C O2 = 1.2 × 10−6 mol cm−3). The constant, 0.2, is adopted when the rotation rate is used in rpm. The HO2 − yield and n value can be derived from the following equations [22]: (2) %(HO2 −) = 200 I r/(I d × N + I r) (3) n = 4 × I d/(I d + Ir/N) where I r is the ring current, I d is the disk current, and N (0.38) is the current-collection efficiency of the ring electrode. The double-layer capacitance (C dl) can be measured using the capacitive current related to the double-layer range. 2.4 Fabrication and evaluation of Zinc-air batteries The ZABs were fabricated in a homemade cell with a Zn plate as anode and 6 mol L−1 KOH solution as electrolyte (6 mol L−1 KOH and 0.2 mol L−1 zinc acetate for cycling test). Air cathode was fabricated by coating catalyst ink (5 mg mL−1) onto carbon paper (Shanghai Hesen Electric Co., Ltd, HCP135) and dried at 80 °C. The mass loading was 1 mg cm−2. The PAA gel electrolyte for solid-state ZABs was prepared as described in a previous work [23]. Polarization curves were recorded on a CHI 760E workstation, and other data were recorded using a LAND CT2001A battery testing system under ambient conditions. 2.5 Fabrication of water splitting equipment Both the cathode and anode were prepared using CoP X @B-NPC-coated carbon paper with a mass loading of 1 mg cm−2 (1 cm × 1 cm). The water splitting device was driven by two ZABs in series. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structure and composition characterization As shown in Scheme 1 , aniline monomers were polymerized in the presence of phytic acid, forming a hierarchical PANI hydrogel doped with phytic acid. Equipped with abundant surface phytate groups, metal ions can be easily coordinated and anchored in the polymer. Thermal carbonization enables the in-situ formation of metal phosphide nanocrystals embedded in 3D porous carbon nanofibers. PANI with a peculiar skeleton interconnected with benzenoid amines allows surface modification with various dopants (e.g., acids) via electrostatic interactions, thus enhancing the electrical conductivity. Upon increasing the ratio of aniline to phytic acid, the obtained PANI aerogels exhibited a dark cyan color (denoted as B-PANI-PA) and an olive color (denoted as F-PANI-PA), respectively (Fig. S1). Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images (Fig. S2) demonstrated aniline-dependent morphological changes. With increasing aniline content, the coralloid-like morphology of the PANI aerogel for B-PANI-PA changed to a fiber-like morphology of F-PANI-PA. The N2 isotherms (Fig. S3(a)) of the two PANI aerogels exhibited a similar type IV profile, suggesting the presence of mesopores owing to the interconnected interspaces. However, the specific surface area of F-PANI-PA was approximately 740 m2 g−1, which was approximately two-fold larger than that of B-PANI-PA (378 m2 g−1). The pore-size distribution curves (Fig. S3(b)) further confirm the presence of mesopores with diameters < 10 nm and large pore volumes of 0.90 and 0.52 cm3 g−1 for F-PANI-PA and B-PANI-PA, respectively. These results demonstrate that the porous structure can be adjusted by varying the aniline-to-phytic acid ratio. The variation in the surface functional groups of the PANI aerogels was investigated using FTIR spectroscopy, as shown in Fig. S4. For B-PANI-PA, two characteristic peaks situated at 1570 and 1487 cm−1 were assigned to the stretching vibration of C=C in the quinoid and benzenoid rings, indicating the emeraldine salt form of PANI [24–26]. For F-PANI-PA, the slight blue-shift of these two peaks to 1574 and 1494 cm−1 indicates the different emeraldine states of polyanline due to the different dopant ratios. The characteristic bands situated at ~1050 and 927 cm−1 were assigned to the antisymmetrical and symmetrical frequencies of the P–O–C groups in PANI-PA, respectively [27,28]. The blue shift of these two peaks in the FT-IR spectra to higher wavenumbers can be attributed to the interactions between the phytate groups and cobalt ions [27]. To further confirm the strong adsorption capability of phytic acid-doped PANI for cobalt ions, the ultraviolet-visible absorption spectrum was obtained by recording the time-dependent change in the peak intensity. Notably, by adjusting the pH from 4 to ~7.3, a dramatic decrease in the absorbance value of the cobalt (II) aqueous solution (Fig. S5) indicated the enhanced absorption capacity of phytic acid-doped PANI for Co ions. As expected, the concentration of Co ions was decisive for the microstructure and phase component of TM x P y . As shown in Fig. 1 , B-NPC prepared by pyrolysis of B-PANI-PA in N2 shows a brachyplast-like structure (Figs. 1(a), (b)). The carbonization of B-PANI-PA and F-PANI-PA under an NH3 atmosphere led to the formation of CoP X @B-NPC and CoP X @F-NPC, showing a 3D porous structure embedded with nanocrystals (Figs. 1(c)–(f)). The porosity is significantly enhanced by the thermal decomposition of organic precursors at temperatures above 1000 °C. In particular, the presence of metal species promotes thermal etching of carbon materials [29]. When NH3 is introduced as a reducing gas, the phytate groups induce in situ formation of metal phosphides under thermal treatment. After adjusting the pH to 7.3, CoP X @B-NPC-7.3 exhibited an increased nanoparticle size at the micrometer scale (Fig. S7). Thus, the enhancement in the adsorption capacity of metal ions would result in nanoparticle aggregation during thermal treatment, demonstrating the crucial role of adsorption capacity in adjusting the final dispersion. HRTEM images of CoP X @B-NPC (Fig. 1(g)), (h)) shows CoP X nanocrystals embedded within an interconnected porous carbon skeleton. The elemental mapping images in Fig. 1(i)) reveal a good distribution of N and O in the carbon skeleton. The overlap of the Co and P regions suggests the formation of a cobalt phosphide. N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms and pore distribution curves (Figs. 2(a), (b)) further elucidate the large pore volumes and broad pore distribution induced by pyrolysis under an NH3 atmosphere. Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) analysis confirms the BET surface area increases from 465, 618 to 694 m2 g−1, while the total pore volume increases from 0.45, 0.65 to 0.86 cm3 g−1 for B-NPC, CoP X @B-NPC and CoP X @F-NPC, respectively. These results are in line with the porous structure observed in the TEM images, indicating the hierarchical porous structures of CoP X @B-NPC and CoP X @F-NPC. XRD patterns revealed the formation of CoP and CoP3 species in CoP X @B-NPC and CoP X @F-NPC, but the absence of detectable cobalt species in B-NPC. The characteristic peaks located at 31.6°, 35.4°, 36.4°, 46.3°, 48.1°, and 56.8° (Fig. 2(c) )) were assigned to the (011), (200), (111), (112), (211), and (301) crystal faces, respectively. The diffraction peaks at 32.8°, 36.9°, 40.6°, 43.9°, 47.1°, 50.1°, and 55.9o were indexed to the (220), (013), (222), (321), (400), (411), and (332) faces of CoP3, respectively. These relatively broad peaks suggest a defect-rich structure. In contrast, the cobalt phosphide phase was pH-dependent, and cobalt-rich Co2P (CoP X @B-NPC-7.3) was obtained at a higher pH because of the increasing metal species adsorbed. This synthetic strategy can be further extended to prepare various metal phosphide species embedded in 3D porous carbon composites with uniform dispersion and tunable compositions. When Co ions were replaced with Fe ions, Fe2P embedded porous carbon materials (denoted as FeP X @B-NPC) were well synthesized (Fig. S8). Raman spectra in Fig. S9 exhibits two characteristic peaks of the G and D bands at approximately 1595 and 1348 cm−1. After pyrolysis under NH3 atmosphere, the increased I D/I G intensity ratio from 0.94 for B-NPC to 1.14 and 1.21 for CoP X @B-NPC and CoP X @F-NPC indicates the formation of abundant edge defects in carbon, possibly producing more active sites for the electrocatalysis. XPS analysis was performed to investigate the elemental composition of the CoP X @NPC surface. XPS survey spectra (Fig. S10) indicate the presence of C, O, N, P, and Co in CoP X @B-NPC and CoP X @F-NPC. The Co 2p 3/2 region (Figs. 2(d) and S11(d)) is deconvoluted into two main peaks situated at ~778.8 and ~781.0 eV, respectively. The peak at 778.8 eV, which is commonly associated with cobalt phosphide, shifted positively from that of Co metal (~778.1 eV) [30]. This suggests a partial positive charge (δ +) of Co, which contributes to the increased electrostatic affinity to OH− for enhanced electrocatalysis [31,32]. The peak at 781.0 eV with a satellite peak was assigned to cobalt (II) due to surface oxidation in the air [33]. The higher proportion of Co (II) in CoP X @B-NPC than in CoP X @F-NPC may be ascribed to the difference in the carbon precursor and pyrolysis process, thus leading to different surface valence states. The P 2p region (Figs. 2(e) and S11(b), (e)) is deconvoluted into two peaks situated at 129.6 and 130.6 eV, assigning to P 2p 3/2 and P 2p 1/2 for phosphide. The P 2p 3/2 binding energy of 129.6 eV shifts negatively from that of P (130.2 eV), suggesting a partial negative charge (δ -) and electron transfer from Co to P [31]. Besides, peaks situated at 132.4 and 133.6 eV are assigned to P–C bond and P–O bond in polyphosphates, indicating partial incoporation of P into carbon skeleton. The N 1s region (Figs. 2(f) and S11(c), (f)) was deconvoluted into four peaks at ~398.4, 400.0, 401.1, and 403.0 eV, assigned to pyridinic, pyrrolic, graphitic, and oxidized nitrogen, respectively. Along with the formation of abundant pores and edge defects, CoP X @B-NPC and CoP X @F-NPC exhibited a higher proportion of pyridinic nitrogen, which may enhance the catalytic activity for the ORR. 3.2 ORR and OER electrocatalytic performance Cyclic voltammetry (CV) curves (Fig. S12), a reduction peak at 0.78 V for the B-NPC electrode shifts positively to 0.82 and 0.84 V for CoP X @F-NPC and CoP X @B-NPC, indicating enhanced ORR catalytic activity. Linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) curves (Fig. 3(a) )) also demonstrate higher ORR activity at the CoP X @NPC electrode, and the half-wave potential (E 1/2) shifts positively from 0.77 for B-NPC to 0.81 for CoP X @F-NPC and 0.84 V for CoP X @B-NPC, comparable to that of Pt/C counterpart. Additionally, the CoP X @B-NPC electrode exhibited a lower Tafel slope of 72 mV dec−1 (Fig. 3(b))) and a higher kinetic current density (j k) of 5.2 mA cm−2 (Fig. S13), indicating the rapid ORR kinetics. CoP X @B-NPC electrode exhibits the highest double-layer capacitance of 19.8 mF cm−2 (Fig. S14) than those of CoP X @F-NPC (12.2 mF cm−2) and B-NPC (11.7 mF cm−2), suggesting the largest electrochemical surface area. These results confirm the synergistic effect between the highly active cobalt phosphide and the 3D porous carbon skeleton on boosting the ORR activity. To further quantify the reaction mechanism for the ORR, LSV curves were obtained at various rotation rates ranging from 400 to 2500 r min−1 (Fig. 3(c))). The electron transfer number (n) values derived from Koutecký-Levich equation in potential range from 0.6 to 0.3 V (vs. RHE) are close to 4 for CoP X @B-NPC. The n values derived from rotating disk-ring electrode (RRDE) measurements for CoP X @B-NPC were also close to 4, along with low peroxide yield less than 8% (Fig. 3(d))). These results suggest that the oxygen reduction proceeds via an efficient four-electron transfer pathway. The chronoamperometric current of the CoP X @B-NPC electrode showed a negligible change with the addition of 1.5 mol L−1 methanol, whereas the commercial Pt/C counterpart showed pronounced current decay as a consequence of the methanol corss-over effect (Fig. S15). These results suggest improved selectivity and stability of CoP X @B-NPC for the ORR. To further demonstrate bifunctional applications, CoP X @NPC also demonstrated decent electrocatalytic activity toward the OER (Fig. 3(e))). To achieve a benchmark current density of 10 mA cm−2, the anodic potentials of 1.52 and 1.57 V are required for CoP X @F-NPC and CoP X @B-NPC, respectively in comparison with B-NPC (1.60 V). Furthermore, the smallest potential difference of 0.87 V at CoP X @B-NPC electrode between the potential at 10 mA cm−2 for OER and E 1/2 for ORR suggests the highest bifunctional catalytic activity (Fig. 3(f))), rivals that of Pt-RuO2 counterpart (0.88 V) and surpasses those of CoP X @F-NPC (0.90 V) and B-NPC (1.12 V) electrodes. To achieve efficient bifunctional activity, good dispersion of cobalt phosphide nanocrystallines in CoP X @B-NPC leads to the exposure of various crystal faces for enhanced electrocatalytic activity. The interconnected 3D porous carbon skeleton imparts high electrical conductivity and provides additional defects to boost bifunctional electrocatalytic performance. 3.3 Zinc-air batteries application The viability and stability of the as-synthesized 3D porous carbon composites in a two-electrode system were evaluated by fabricating rechargeable ZABs using the as-prepared electrocatalyst-coated air electrode. The battery assembled with the CoP X @B-NPC electrode exhibited the highest open-circuit voltage (1.49 V) (Fig. S16). The galvanostatic discharging test (Fig. 4(a) )) demonstrates the excellent rate performance of the ZAB using the CoP X @B-NPC electrocatalyst. At a high current density of 50 mA cm−2, it exhibits the highest discharging potential of 1.16 V and continues to deliver a high voltage of 1.36 V when restored to 2 mA cm−2. The power density plots (Fig. 4(b))) show the highest power output of 368 mW cm−2 for CoP X @B-NPC, outperforming those of Pt-RuO2 (237 mW cm−2), CoP X @F-NPC (209 mW cm−2), and B-NPC (143 mW cm−2). CoP X @B-NPC features hierarchical porous carbon skeleton with phosphorus-rich cobalt phosphide nanocrystallines, which can expose high density of crystal faces and defects for better electrochemical performance. Moreover, the ZAB using the CoP X @B-NPC electrode exhibited a large specific capacity of 762 mAh gZn −1 with a high energy density of 937 Wh kgZn −1 (current density of 25 mA cm−2) (Fig. 4(c))), surpassing its Pt-RuO2 counterpart with a specific capacity of 730 mA h gZn −1 and an energy density of 900 Wh kgZn −1. As shown in Fig. 4(d)), the ZAB with the CoP X @B-NPC electrode exhibited a low potential gap (0.72 V at a current density of 40 mA cm−2 because of efficient bifunctional activity [8]. The ZAB using the CoP X @B-NPC electrode (Fig. 4(e))) demonstrated stable cycling durability with a slight voltage decay after 260 h. In contrast, the battery using the Pt-RuO2 electrode undergoes severe charging polarization after 30 h, which is attributed to poor catalytic stability. Hence, the efficient and stable catalytic performance of CoP X @B-NPC offers the advantage of enhanced cycling durability of ZAB. Moreover, the interconnected 3D porous carbon skeleton maintained its electronic integrity for stable cycling. To demonstrate its viability in flexible electronic devices, a solid-state ZAB was fabricated in a sandwich configuration with a polyacrylic acid (PAA) gel as both the electrolyte and separator. As shown in Fig. 5(a) ), the open-circuit voltage of 1.48 V for the solid-state ZAB based on the CoP X @B-NPC electrode was the highest, indicating the excellent intrinsic electrochemical performance of CoP X @B-NPC. The galvanostatic discharging curves at various current densities (Fig. 5(b))) demonstrate good rate capability. The polarization curves (Fig. 5(c))) exhibited a maximum power density of 160 mW cm−2 for the ZAB using the CoP X @B-NPC electrode, outperforming those of CoP X @F-NPC (125 mW cm−2), Pt-RuO2 (74 mW cm−2), and B-NPC (66 mW cm−2). The improved power density could be attributed not only to the enhanced electrocatalytic activity but also to the improved mass-transfer performance [34]. For CoP X @B-NPC, the interconnected hierarchical porous network with abundant pores, edges, and corners provided sufficient mass transfer pathways for a high power output. The highly efficient bifunctional activity and porous network of CoP X @B-NPC further endowed it with decent charge/discharge performance (Fig. 5(d))). The galvanostatic cycling test (Fig. 5(e))) further elucidated the excellent durability of ZAB using the CoP X @B-NPC electrode for 35 h. In contrast, the ZABs using B-NPC and Pt-RuO2 electrodes showed obvious voltage decay after 20 h, possibly due to catalyst deterioration. Moreover, no apparent voltage decay was observed under bending (Fig. 5(f))). The good mechanical durability can be attributed to the sandwich configuration and intimate interfacial contact between the gel electrolyte and porous carbon electrocatalyst for fast interfacial mass/electron transfer [35,36]. The as-prepared CoP X @B-NPC and CoP X @F-NPC also demonstrated efficient HER performance with overpotentials of 230 and 210 mV, respectively, to reach a current density of 10 mA cm−2 (Fig. S17). The decent HER, OER, and OER activities of CoP X @B-NPC enabled the fabrication of water-splitting equipment powered by ZABs with CoP X @B-NPC electrodes (Fig. S18). Typically, gas evolution rates of O2 and H2 are approximately 1.39 and 2.78 μL s−1, respectively (Fig. S19) with a ratio of approximately 1:2, suggesting efficient water splitting into O2 and H2 [33]. 4 Conclusions In summary, TM x P y -embedded 3D porous N,P-doped carbon was synthesized as a highly efficient and stable electrocatalyst through the interfacial coordination of TM ions with phytate-rich PANI hydrogel, followed by controlled pyrolysis. Interestingly, with the increasing concentration of cobalt ions adsorbed by increasing the pH of the solution, the phase composition of cobalt phosphide can be regulated by pyrolysis. The resultant 3D N,P-doped porous carbon with well-dispersed cobalt phosphide NPs contributed synergistically to the trifunctional electrocatalytic activity toward ORR, OER, and HER. These unique electrocatalytic advantages endow the fabrication of ZABs in both aqueous and solid-state electrolytes with high power output and good cycling/mechanical stability. Furthermore, water splitting can be achieved by using the same carbon-based composite catalysts for high-performance Zn-air batteries, leading to good gas generation rate. This study provides a generalized and clean strategy to synthesize porous carbon electrocatalysts with suitable metal phosphides for multiple electrocatalytic applications. Electronic supporting information Supporting information is available in the online version of this article. Conflicts of interest The authors declare no competing interest. coredata.dc:description: Abstract The rational design of efficient and stable carbon-based electrocatalysts for oxygen reduction and oxygen evolution reactions is crucial for improving energy density and long-term stability of rechargeable zinc-air batteries (ZABs). Herein, a general and controllable synthesis method was developed to prepare three-dimensional (3D) porous carbon composites embedded with diverse metal phosphide nanocrystallites by interfacial coordination of transition metal ions with phytic acid-doped polyaniline networks and subsequent pyrolysis. Phytic acid as the dopant of polyaniline provides favorable anchoring sites for metal ions owing to the coordination interaction. Specifically, adjusting the concentration of adsorbed cobalt ions can achieve the phase regulation of transition metal phosphides. Thus, with abundant cobalt phosphide nanoparticles and nitrogen- and phosphorus-doping sites, the obtained carbon-based electrocatalysts exhibited efficient electrocatalytic activities toward oxygen reduction and evolution reactions. Consequently, the fabricated ZABs exhibited a high energy density, high power density of 368 mW cm−2, and good cycling/mechanical stability, which could power water splitting for integrated device fabrication with high gas yields.
coredata.prism:publisher: Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, the Chinese Academy of Sciences. Published by Elsevier B.V.
coredata.dc:title: In-situ formation of cobalt phosphide nanoparticles confined in three-dimensional porous carbon for high-performing zinc-air battery and water splitting
coredata.prism:copyright: Copyright © 2022 Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, the Chinese Academy of Sciences. Published by Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
